title: Make shields...shields again. (Shield Duration is actually ridiculous)
body:
I specifically remember the duration of Riven's Valor (E) was significantly shortened on the basis of Riot wanting her shield to be used more intuitively.

> **Patch 4.1 **
We’re reducing the duration of Valor to hit some of Riven’s flexibility in lane – if she’s going to rely on Valor’s shield to trade damage, she’ll need to commit quickly or risk losing the shield.

Riven's shield duration from Valor is currently 1.5 seconds. Meanwhile:
{{champion:40}} Eye of the Storm (E) 5 Second Shield Duration, 5.5 Second CD at Rank 5 with 45% CDR
{{champion:117}} Help, Pix! (E) 6 Second Shield Duration, 5.5 Second CD at Rank 5 with 45% CDR
{{champion:25}} Black Shield (E) 5 Second Shield Duration, 8.25 Second CD at Rank 5 with 45% CDR

Keep in mind that these all have 650-900 Range so they can sit literally Caitlyn's Auto-Attack Range behind the rest of her team casting Shields from complete safety. Keep in mind that their Shield durations are as long or almost as long as their cooldowns. Keep in mind that they all have multiple forms of CC on top of this that would make most Tanks in the game envious (Janna can literally hit the enemy backline from her own backline with her Q that significantly outranges a fully channeled Xerath Q)

Please nerf the living shit out of shield duration please and thank you Riot.

It doesn't even make sense from a logical standpoint. People don't walk around a battlefield with their shields held over their faces. They deflect a blow and keep swinging. This is how shields should work in LoL.

EDIT: {{champion:43}} Inspire (E) 4 Second Shield Duration, 4.4 Second CD at Rank 5 with 45% CDR

EDIT 2: The only reasonable Shield Duration in the game for a Shield that can be cast on an Ally is on {{champion:427}} Triggerseed (E) (2 Second shield duration) and even then, it's because the shield detonates to deal damage and slow nearby targets.

replies.body:
I play offensive themed supports (really, one trick Zilean) and I think drastically cutting shield duration will straight up dumpster shield users in a huge way. You need something less binary and more dynamic.

The best solution is to make all shields 'decay' over time. This has a nice skill-gate built right into it, and makes it possible to play around shields in a much more meaningful way. (waiting out SOME of the shields block amount before bursting.) 

This also has a secondary effect of negating 'shield stacking' which your method does not, as each shield could have its own 'decay' effect, so stacking multiple shields on a single target causes the decay speed to effectively 'double'. 

THIRDLY, and where I think the idea really shines is that it adds a new lever to balance around. If shields are still too strong, up the rate of decay.
If Riot _really_ cared about shield stacking, they would make them work like non-knockup CC where the most recent CC replaces the previous one and consequently negates the rest of its effect.

Riven has loads of damage, mobility and CC in her kit on top of an AD scaling shield. Of course her shield is going to be weaker than a champ who does nothing but keep people alive, and can't really exist on their own.

No. A shield is a shield and shield stacking from Supports is one of the biggest problems in the game right now. Either shield duration needs to be nerfed, or things like shield size and cooldown need to start getting hefty nerfs.

So... why weren't shields complained about for 7-8 years? 

Hm. Weird.

Because we didn't have things like Windspeaker's Blessing/Ardent Censer/Aery substantially buffing them. Access to CDR and Gold-Effient Support items has also improved significantly over the last 7-8 years meaning that what used to be 8-10 second CD shields are now 5-6 second CD shields.

shields on supports used to have zero ap behind them and zero shield amping abilities. So the max hp on a shield used to be around 250-300 hp even late game. Literally half to 35% of what they are now. Also support items were significantly less powerful and supports didnt have access to the income to afford more then 1-2 of them.

By contrast, CC is an incredibly arbitrary example. There are probably a dozen different forms of CC, and as many ways to apply them as there are champions with CC. You cannot make an apples to apples comparison between any of them.

Perhaps some definitions would be useful:
Tactical counterplay: Actions which you can take during combat to nullify or mitigate the strength of a champion, ability, or strategy.
Strategic counterplay: Actions which you can take outside of combat to nullify or mitigate the strength of a champion, ability, or strategy.

For example: Blitzcrank. You see the enemy support lock in Blitzcrank. What do you do? You pick tanky. That's strategic counterplay. But it's also the worst kind of strategic outplay: the kind that relies on pick order RNG.
Blitzcrank is one of the most irritating supports to play against, and that's because counterpicking used to be his only counterplay: if you didn't pick tanky, all you could do in game is dodge hooks and wait for the inevitable. But then Riot nerfed the healing power, then the gold generation on Relic Shield. Now you can poke down his carry over time (tactical counterplay), and you can patiently wait, playing safe until the late game where his power drops off due to low gold income (strategic counterplay).
